Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Virtualized Wireless Networks and Their Impact on Capacity Markets

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops a new vision for wireless networks, predicated on the creation of service-driven virtual networks constructed from a pool for resources that belong to a variety of stakeholders. The resources include spectrum, physical infrastructure, and control and management support, and the stakeholders include traditional mobile operators, operators of WiFi access networks, businesses and households that support wireless connectivity through small cell deployment, traffic aggregators (such as Mobile Virtual Network Operators [MVNOs]), and regulators. The resulting architecture separates the consumer-facing service provision from the technologies used to construct the network, enabling the disintermediation of current wireless service provision systems. Moving the point at which network access transactions take place up the value chain (or the protocol stack) means that a greater range of service types can be provided to consumers without requiring large up-front capital investments on the part of the (consumer-facing) service providers. This will have profound impact on both industry and society, affecting the way that these networks are designed and built, spectrum and infrastructure resources are managed, and pricing structures for services provided over the network.

This project first defines a new architecture that enables the virtualization of a wireless network over a combination of spectrum licensed under different regimes and infrastructure with different ownership. Relying on game theoretic and market models of virtual network construction, new resource management mechanisms are designed to select the appropriate set of resources to build a virtual wireless network with given coverage and capacity requirements. Combinatorial auctions for multiple objects are practical mechanisms for the dynamic allocation and aggregation of resources for such a virtualized wireless network. In analyzing the impact of the proposed architecture on spectrum markets, a key question is whether the incorporation of a virtualized spectrum commodity influences the viability of these markets (as measured by the liquidity outcome), and how this compares to previous scenarios in which the traded commodity was the physical spectrum resource or ?naked spectrum.? Finally, this project explores how markets in virtual wireless capacity would work when implemented in current wireless networks, in the context of LTE-Advanced and expected 5G developments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modern wireless networks, such as cellular networks and WiFi networks, as well as more specialized networks used in the transportation industry and the military, are extremely complex. These networks make use of many different types of resources with many different capabilities. Some of the resources needed to create a wireless network include base station or access point hardware, licenses to access the radio spectrum (or unlicensed spectrum that can be used), wired networks that provide backhaul, and core network services such as identity management and billing. 

Over the last decade, one of the most important paradigms in computing has been virtualization. The idea is that a computer system can be "virtualized", after which it can be run on different computer hardware at different data centers in the cloud. Such a virtualized computer system can be given different physical resources (processors, memory, hard drive space) depending upon its needs, can be easily scaled up or down (a single instance of the system can be run in one place or thousands can be run in data centers around the world), and a single "computer" in hardware can run many virtual computer systems simultaneously. 

This project has explored the application of the idea of "virtualization" to wireless networks. The idea is similar to the virtualization of a computer system described in the prior paragraph. Many components needed to create wireless networks have already been deployed, especially in populated areas. What if these components could be used to create multiple "virtual wireless networks" supporting different applications and different service providers with different network requirements at the same time? That is the idea that has been explored in this project.

One of the first outcomes of the project was the creation of a three-layer architecture for the virtualization of wireless networks. At the top of this architecture are service providers. A service provider is an entity that wants to create a wireless network (across a region, a nation, or even the world) for some particular purpose. Some networks might be designed to support traditional cellular access via smart phones, other networks could be built to support the manegement of a commercial vehicle fleet, others could be built to support a streaming movie service like Netflix, still others could be built to support public safety, and so on. At the bottom of this architecture are resource providers. A resource provider is an entity that provides physical resources to support a wireless network. These resources could be base stations or access points, or licenses for radio spectrum access, or a wired network with connectivity to the internet, or computing services that can be used to support the network. In the middle, and the most innovative portion of our network architecture, sits one or more virtual network builders (VNBs). The responsibility of these VNBs is to orchestrate the networks desired by service providers out of the resources offered by resource providers. They do this by taking specifications for desired networks from service providers, selecting the appropriate set of resources from those offered by resource providers, and then instantiating the networks required to meet the service providers' demands. The idea is that service providers may select from multiple VNBs, which will receive some payment for orchestrating the underlying networks, and that VNBs will also pay for the resources that they use. 

Much of the work in the project has also gone towards studying the resource allocation problem faced by VNBs. For one thing, it is not clear how a service provider should express their demand for a network. In this project, we have defined an appropriate notion of service provider demand, which could be used to specify the desired network to a VNB. This same description of demand could then be used to create a Service Level Agreement (SLA) between the service provider and the VNB. We have then extensively studied the problem faced by VNBs in selecting resources to create the desired networks, and we have proposed realistic ways for a VNB to make these selections in a way that uses resources efficiently and assures that service provider demands are met.

The project has also studied the markets that arise surrounding our proposed architecture. In particular, we have extensively studied the market between service providers and VNBs using the concept of a matching market. Namely, we have studied the dynamics that result when service providers have multiple VNBs from which to choose, and tried to understand whether such a market will be rich and sustainable or not. In some of the final work in the project, we have integrated the market simulations just described with the resource allocation work to create a complete simulation that enabled us to study a full virtualized wireless ecosystem.
